message_1: In a competition, there are 7 teams participating. In how many different ways can the competition end, assuming there are no ties?
message_2:
In a competition with 7 teams and no ties, we can use the concept of permutations to determine the number of different ways the competition can end. 

A permutation is an arrangement of objects in a specific order. In this case, we want to arrange the 7 teams in order from 1st place to 7th place. 

The number of permutations can be calculated using the formula:

P(n, r) = n! / (n - r)!

where n is the total number of objects (teams) and r is the number of objects we want to arrange (also teams, since we want to arrange all of them).

In this case, n = 7 and r = 7.

P(7, 7) = 7! / (7 - 7)!

P(7, 7) = 7! / 0!

Since 0! is equal to 1:

P(7, 7) = 7!

Now, we just need to calculate 7! (7 factorial):

7! = 7 × 6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1 = 5040

So, there are 5040 different ways the competition can end with no ties.
